title: The twins who tricked the Maya gods of death - Ilan Stavans

title: The sleep disorder you might not know you have - Alayna Vaughan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of snoring?

options.label: A
options.text: Relaxation of muscles around the respiratory tract

options.label: B
options.text: Blockages in the airway

options.label: C
options.text: Congestion and anatomical features

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of the above factors

multiple-choice.question: What is obstructive sleep apnea, and what is a common symptom of it?

options.label: A
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep, and a common symptom is loud snoring

options.label: B
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by blockages in the airway, and a common symptom is insomnia

options.label: C
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by difficulty breathing, and a common symptom is a runny nose

options.label: D
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, and a common symptom is a headache

multiple-choice.question: What is central sleep apnea, and how does it differ from obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Central sleep apnea occurs when the brain temporarily fails to regulate the body's breathing, and it is characterized by loud snoring

options.label: B
options.text: Central sleep apnea occurs when the brain temporarily fails to regulate the body's breathing, and it is characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep

options.label: C
options.text: Central sleep apnea occurs when the brain temporarily fails to regulate the body's breathing, and it is characterized by a runny nose

options.label: D
options.text: Central sleep apnea occurs when the brain temporarily fails to regulate the body's breathing, and it is characterized by a headache

multiple-choice.question: What are some risk factors for developing obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Larger tongues, thicker necks, and smaller jaws

options.label: B
options.text: Older age, weight gain, and drinking alcohol before bed

options.label: C
options.text: Smoking, high blood pressure, and a family history of sleep apnea

options.label: D
options.text: B

multiple-choice.question: What is a common treatment for obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: CPAP machines, which deliver a constant stream of pressurized air to keep the airway open

options.label: B
options.text: Oral appliances, which are custom-made to fit the mouth and throat

options.label: C
options.text: Surgery, which is usually considered if non-invasive treatments do not work

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What are some lifestyle changes that can help alleviate obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Limiting alcohol consumption before bed, elevating the head, and avoiding sleeping on the back

options.label: B
options.text: Exercising regularly, losing weight, and quitting smoking

options.label: C
options.text: Getting enough sleep, reducing stress, and avoiding caffeine

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What are the effects of obstructive sleep apnea on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to high blood pressure, heart disease, and stroke

options.label: B
options.text: It can cause headaches, decreased concentration, and chronic fatigue

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to weight gain, obesity, and diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain in regulating breathing during sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain temporarily fails to regulate the body's breathing, leading to central sleep apnea

options.label: B
options.text: The brain regulates the body's breathing, but can be affected by sleep apnea

options.label: C
options.text: The brain is not involved in regulating breathing during sleep

options.label: D
options.text: The brain regulates breathing during sleep, but can be affected by sleep apnea

multiple-choice.question: What are the effects of obstructive sleep apnea on the cardiovascular system?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to high blood pressure, heart disease, and stroke

options.label: B
options.text: It can cause headaches, decreased concentration, and chronic fatigue

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to weight gain, obesity, and diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to seek medical attention for obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: To alleviate symptoms and prevent complications

options.label: B
options.text: To treat underlying conditions and improve quality of life

options.label: C
options.text: To diagnose and manage related health problems

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What are some preliminary trials that have shown promise in alleviating obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Limiting alcohol consumption before bed

options.label: B
options.text: Elevating the head and avoiding sleeping on the back

options.label: C
options.text: Mouth and throat exercises

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of people who suffer from obstructive sleep apnea without being aware of it?
What are some common symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Loud snoring, difficulty breathing, and morning headaches

options.label: B
options.text: Insomnia, restlessness, and daytime fatigue

options.label: C
options.text: Coughing, wheezing, and difficulty swallowing

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Age-related changes in the airway

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain and obesity

options.label: C
options.text: Smoking and high blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the most effective treatment for obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: CPAP machines

options.text: Surgery

title: 3 secrets of resilient people - Lucy Hone

multiple-choice.question: What motivated the speaker to start studying resilience research?

options.label: A
options.text: She was trying to help her community after the Christchurch earthquakes.

options.label: B
options.text: She wanted to find ways to bring scientific findings to everyday people.

options.label: C
options.text: She was asked by the American army to train soldiers to be mentally fit.

options.label: D
options.text: She was experiencing personal struggles with her own resilience.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's initial reaction to the advice given to her after her daughter's death?

options.label: A
options.text: She felt grateful for the support and felt hopeful.

options.label: B
options.text: She felt overwhelmed and powerless.

options.label: C
options.text: She was skeptical but willing to try new strategies.

options.label: D
options.text: She was angry and resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy the speaker relies on for resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on the good things in life.

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing where to select attention.

options.label: C
options.text: Recognizing that suffering is part of life.

options.label: D
options.text: Asking if what she's doing is helping or harming her.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the way humans are wired, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: We are too focused on the good things in life.

options.label: B
options.text: We are too good at noticing threats and weaknesses.

options.label: C
options.text: We are too focused on the present moment.

options.label: D
options.text: We are wired to notice threats and weaknesses, which can lead to a permanent stress response.

multiple-choice.question: What is benefit finding, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on the negative aspects of a situation.

options.label: B
options.text: Finding things to be grateful for.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding difficult emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the present moment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the experiment conducted by Martin Seligman and colleagues in 2005?

options.label: A
options.text: The Resilience Study.

options.label: B
options.text: The Gratitude Experiment.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benefit Finding Study.

options.label: D
options.text: The Positive Psychology Study.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's go-to question in the days after her daughter's death?

options.label: A
options.text: Is what I'm doing helping or harming me?

options.label: B
options.text: Is this what I want to do?

options.label: C
options.text: Is this what I need to do?

options.label: D
options.text: Is this what I should do?

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to people who feel like they are not coming back from a difficult situation?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's impossible to come back from it.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's going to take a long time to come back from it.

options.label: C
options.text: That they should lean into the strategies and think again.

options.label: D
options.text: That they should give up.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main message about resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's a fixed trait that some people have and some people don't.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's a difficult trait to develop.

options.label: C
options.text: That it requires ordinary processes and a willingness to give them a try.

options.label: D
options.text: That it's not important for everyday life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's experience of being a resilience expert and then becoming a grieving mother?

options.label: A
options.text: She was initially overwhelmed by her new role as a grieving mother.

options.label: B
options.text: She was skeptical of the advice given to her by others.

options.label: C
options.text: She was flung to the other side of the equation, waking up with a whole new identity.

options.label: D
options.text: She was angry and resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's reaction to the leaflets and resources provided to her after her daughter's death?

options.label: A
options.text: She felt grateful for the support and felt hopeful.

options.label: B
options.text: She felt overwhelmed and powerless.

options.label: C
options.text: She was skeptical but willing to try new strategies.

options.label: D
options.text: She was angry and resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the importance of hope in the grieving process?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's not necessary to have hope in the grieving process.

options.label: B
options.text: That hope is not a realistic expectation in the grieving process.

options.label: C
options.text: That hope is essential for navigating the grieving process.

options.label: D
options.text: That hope is not a priority in the grieving process.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three strategies the speaker relies on for resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on the good things in life, choosing where to select attention, and asking if what you're doing is helping or harming you.

options.label: B
options.text: Recognizing that suffering is part of life, being good at noticing threats and weaknesses, and tuning into the good.

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing on the negative aspects of a situation, avoiding difficult emotions, and ignoring the present moment.

options.label: D
options.text: Being angry and resistant to change, giving up, and not having hope.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's experience of conducting a self-experiment after her daughter's death?

options.label: A
options.text: She was trying to prove the effectiveness of resilience strategies.

options.label: B
options.text: She was testing the limits of her own resilience.

options.label: C
options.text: She was using her research to help her community after the Christchurch earthquakes.

options.label: D
options.text: She was conducting a self-experiment to learn how to cope with her grief.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the nature of resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's a fixed trait that some people either have or don't have.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's a difficult trait to develop.

options.label: C
options.text: That it requires ordinary processes and a willingness to give them a try.

options.label: D
options.text: That it's not important for everyday life.

options.label: A
options.text: She felt overwhelmed and powerless.

options.label: B
options.text: She was skeptical but willing to try new strategies.

options.label: C
options.text: She needed hope and a journey through her grief.

options.label: D
options.text: She was angry and resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's experience of working with her community after the Christchurch earthquakes?

options.label: A
options.text: She was trying to prove the effectiveness of resilience strategies.

options.label: B
options.text: She was testing the limits of her own resilience.

options.label: C
options.text: She was using her research to help her community after the Christchurch earthquakes.

options.label: D
options.text: She was conducting a self-experiment to learn how to cope with her grief.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the importance of gratitude in the grieving process?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's not necessary to feel grateful in the grieving process.

options.label: B
options.text: That gratitude is not a realistic expectation in the grieving process.

options.label: C
options.text: That gratitude is essential for navigating the grieving process.

options.label: D
options.text: That gratitude is not a priority in the grieving process.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's experience of being a resilience expert and then becoming a grieving mother?

options.label: A
options.text: She was initially overwhelmed by her new role as a grieving mother.

options.label: B
options.text: She was skeptical of the advice given to her by others.

options.label: C
options.text: She was flung to the other side of the equation, waking up with a whole new identity.

options.label: D
options.text: She was angry and resistant to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the nature of resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's a fixed trait that some people have and some people don't.

title: The simplest math problem no one can solve

multiple-choice.question: What is the conjecture that every positive integer, when applied to the 3x+1 rules, will eventually end up in the four, two, one loop?

options.label: A
options.text: The Collatz conjecture

options.label: B
options.text: The Ulam conjecture

options.label: C
options.text: The Kakutani problem

options.label: D
options.text: The Syracuse problem

multiple-choice.question: According to Jeffrey Lagarias, what advice did he give to a senior in college who was interested in working on the 3x+1 problem?

options.label: A
options.text: He told them to focus on established mathematics to establish themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: He told them to work on the problem immediately and ignore established mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: He told them to seek guidance from other mathematicians.

options.label: D
options.text: He told them to focus on applications of the 3x+1 problem.

multiple-choice.question: What is the distribution of leading digits in the hailstone numbers that is not unique to the 3x+1 problem?

options.label: A
options.text: Benford's law

options.label: B
options.text: The normal distribution

options.label: C
options.text: The Poisson distribution

options.label: D
options.text: The uniform distribution

multiple-choice.question: According to Terry Tao, what is the result of his analysis of the 3x+1 problem?

options.label: A
options.text: Almost all numbers will eventually end up larger than any arbitrary function f of x.

options.label: B
options.text: Almost all numbers will eventually end up in the four, two, one loop.

options.label: C
options.text: Almost all numbers will eventually end up smaller than any arbitrary function f of x.

options.label: D
options.text: Almost all numbers will eventually end up equal to any arbitrary function f of x.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the idea that almost all numbers have a number in their sequence that is arbitrarily small?

options.label: A
options.text: The statistical version of the Collatz conjecture

options.label: B
options.text: The normal distribution

options.label: C
options.text: Benford's law

options.label: D
options.text: The Collatz conjecture

multiple-choice.question: According to the narrator, what is the most convincing piece of evidence supporting the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: Terry Tao's proof that almost all numbers have a number in their sequence that is arbitrarily small.

options.label: B
options.text: The fact that all numbers up to 2^68 have been tested and obey the Collatz conjecture.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that the distribution of leading digits in the hailstone numbers follows Benford's law.

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that the 3x+1 problem has been shown to be turing-complete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the idea that a mathematical problem may be undecidable?

options.label: A
options.text: The halting problem

options.label: B
options.text: The Collatz conjecture

options.label: C
options.text: The statistical version of the Collatz conjecture

options.label: D
options.text: The problem of decidability

multiple-choice.question: According to the narrator, what is the problem with trying to find a counterexample to the Collatz conjecture by brute force?

options.label: A
options.text: The time it takes to search exhaustively is too long.

options.label: B
options.text: The computational power required to search exhaustively is too great.

options.label: C
options.text: The space of all possibilities is too big to search exhaustively.

options.label: D
options.text: The mathematical tools required to search exhaustively are too complex.

multiple-choice.question: According to the narrator, why is the Collatz conjecture difficult to prove true?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a complex problem.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a difficult problem.

options.label: C
options.text: Because everyone is trying to prove it true, which means almost no one is looking for counterexamples.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a false problem.

multiple-choice.question: According to the narrator, what is the value of the counterexample to the Polya conjecture proposed by C. Brian Haselgrove in 1958?

options.label: A
options.text: 1.845 times 10 to the 361

options.label: B
options.text: 1.845 times 10 to the 360

options.label: C
options.text: 1.845 times 10 to the 362

options.label: D
options.text: 1.845 times 10 to the 363

multiple-choice.question: According to the narrator, what is the difference between a problem being difficult and a problem being undecidable?

options.label: A
options.text: A problem is difficult if it is complex, but a problem is undecidable if it is impossible to solve.

options.label: B
options.text: A problem is difficult if it is hard to solve, but a problem is undecidable if it is impossible to determine its solvability.

options.label: C
options.text: A problem is difficult if it is hard to solve, but a problem is undecidable if it is too hard to solve.

options.label: D
options.text: A problem is difficult if it is hard to solve, but a problem is undecidable if it is impossible to solve.

multiple-choice.question: According to the narrator, what is the problem with trying to find a counterexample to the Collatz conjecture by brute force?

options.label: A
options.text: The time it takes to search exhaustively is too long.

options.label: B
options.text: The computational power required to search exhaustively is too great.

options.label: C
options.text: The space of all possibilities is too big to search exhaustively.

options.label: D
options.text: The mathematical tools required to search exhaustively are too complex.

title: What few people know about the program that "saved" America - Meg Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What was the unemployment rate in the United States during the third winter of the Great Depression in 1932?

options.label: A
options.text: One in five Americans

options.label: B
options.text: One in four Americans

options.label: C
options.text: One in three Americans

options.label: D
options.text: One in two Americans

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Democratic competitor of Republican President Herbert Hoover in the 1932 election?

options.label: A
options.text: Franklin D. Roosevelt

options.label: B
options.text: Theodore Roosevelt

options.label: C
options.text: Woodrow Wilson

options.label: D
options.text: Al Smith

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the comprehensive set of legislation proposed by Franklin D. Roosevelt to support struggling citizens and put the country back to work?

options.label: A
options.text: The New Deal

options.label: B
options.text: The Great Society

options.label: C
options.text: The Fair Deal

options.label: D
options.text: The Economic Recovery Plan

multiple-choice.question: What was the main priority of the New Deal's first hundred days in office?

options.label: A
options.text: Stabilizing the banks

options.label: B
options.text: Creating jobs for workers

options.label: C
options.text: Providing relief to farmers

options.label: D
options.text: Building infrastructure

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the government agency created to guarantee that deposited funds would always be available?

options.label: A
options.text: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation

options.label: B
options.text: Federal Emergency Relief Administration

options.label: C
options.text: Agricultural Adjustment Administration

options.label: D
options.text: Civilian Conservation Corps

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the Civilian Conservation Corps?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide relief to farmers

options.label: B
options.text: To create jobs for workers

options.label: C
options.text: To employ young men for projects like tree planting, irrigation, and fire prevention

options.label: D
options.text: To build infrastructure

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the labor act that granted unions the right to collective bargaining?

options.label: A
options.text: The Wagner Act

options.label: B
options.text: The Fair Labor Standards Act

options.label: C
options.text: The National Labor Relations Act

options.label: D
options.text: The Labor Management Relations Act

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the program that provided old-age pensions, unemployment insurance, disability benefits, and welfare assistance?

options.label: A
options.text: The Social Security Act

options.label: B
options.text: The New Deal

options.label: C
options.text: The Great Society

options.label: D
options.text: The Economic Recovery Plan

multiple-choice.question: How did the New Deal's impact on Black communities vary widely, depending on the region?

options.label: A
options.text: Black communities in the North received more jobs and benefits, while those in the South received fewer

options.label: B
options.text: Black communities in the South received more jobs and benefits, while those in the North received fewer

options.label: C
options.text: The New Deal had an equal impact on Black communities in both the North and the South

options.label: D
options.text: The New Deal had no impact on Black communities

multiple-choice.question: What was the long-term effect of the New Deal on the US economy?

options.label: A
options.text: The economy fully recovered by the end of the 1930s

options.label: B
options.text: The economy continued to struggle until the country's mobilization for World War II

options.label: C
options.text: The New Deal led to a period of rapid economic growth

options.label: D
options.text: The New Deal had no impact on the economy

title: The epic of Gilgamesh, the king who tried to conquer death - Soraya Field Fiorio

multiple-choice.question: In what ancient city in northern Iraq was the library discovered that contained the Epic of Gilgamesh?

options.label: A
options.text: Uruk

options.label: B
options.text: Nineveh

options.label: C
options.text: Babylon

options.label: D
options.text: Ur

multiple-choice.question: Which goddess created a rival for Gilgamesh to tame him?

options.label: A
options.text: Ishtar

options.label: B
options.text: Aruru

options.label: C
options.text: Shiduri

options.label: D
options.text: Utanapishti

options.label: A
options.text: Humbaba

options.label: B
options.text: Bull of Heaven

options.label: C
options.text: Scorpion people

options.label: D
options.text: Gemstone trees

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the city from invaders

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy crops and kill people

options.label: C
options.text: To prove her strength in combat

options.label: D
options.text: To get Gilgamesh's attention

multiple-choice.question: What was the main purpose of Gilgamesh's journey beyond the cosmic mountains?

options.label: A
options.text: To prove his strength in combat

options.label: B
options.text: To find immortality

options.label: C
options.text: To defeat the Bull of Heaven

options.label: D
options.text: To retrieve the magical plant

multiple-choice.question: What advice did the goddess Shiduri give to Gilgamesh?

options.label: A
options.text: To give up his quest for immortality and enjoy his life

options.label: B
options.text: To continue his journey to find immortality

options.label: C
options.text: To stay in the city and rule as king

options.label: D
options.text: To return to Uruk and rule as king

multiple-choice.question: Who was the immortal man who lived after a great flood?

options.label: A
options.text: Utanapishti

options.label: B
options.text: Gilgamesh

options.label: C
options.text: Enkidu

options.label: D
options.text: Ashurbanipal

multiple-choice.question: What was the task that Utanapishti set for Gilgamesh to conquer?

options.label: A
options.text: To stay awake for seven days

options.label: B
options.text: To retrieve the magical plant

options.label: C
options.text: To give up his quest for immortality

options.label: D
options.text: To accept that death comes for everyone

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the magical plant that granted eternal youth?

options.label: A
options.text: It was given to Gilgamesh by Utanapishti

options.label: B
options.text: It was retrieved by Gilgamesh from the bottom of the ocean

options.label: C
options.text: It was stolen by a snake on Gilgamesh's way home

options.label: D
options.text: It was lost forever in the city of Uruk

multiple-choice.question: What did Gilgamesh do with his story after he realized his mortality?

options.text: He destroyed the tablets and forgot about it

options.label: B
options.text: He wrote it on a lapis lazuli tablet and buried it under the city walls

options.label: C
options.text: He shared it with the people of Uruk

options.label: D
options.text: He kept it to himself and never told anyone

options.label: A
options.text: Uruk

options.label: B
options.text: Nineveh

options.text: 3000 BCE

options.label: D
